ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had live virtual lecture 3 days a week and asynchronous activities 2 days a week.
Asynchronous days

MWF virtual seminar
TTh asynchronous work
Asychronous work Thursdays and Tuesdays with MWF being zoom seminar.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Grammar solidification and improvement, improvement speaking freely.
learned German!
Better skills in German speaking, reading, and writing
We did a lot of practice with the grammatical forms from GMAN 120, and introduced slightly more complex variations.
I learned more german words, grammar, and structure. I learned to edit my writing in German and how German culture is not necessarily the same as represented by international media.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: engagement was high and encouraged

Weaknesses: high workload
German online is just really rough. hard to learn, less talking in class, dont like having shared PowerPoints
A lot of work, but the teacher did a great job helping us and answering questions

The live virtual elements of this class were very enjoyable. The pacing was good, and I feel that I have a much stronger understanding of the grammatical forms that I saw in earlier German courses. The asynchronous elements were a bit miserable.
Zoom Seminar works well, asynchronous work can pile up however. Less async work would make the class more enjoyable and doable.

It was hard to do this course virtually, but Thorsten did a great job keeping us engaged for the virtual discussions. It was also really nice to have asynchronous work assigned two days a week, but the workload on these days could vary greatly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The asynchronous days were a lot of work and took much longer than the synchronous lectures + homework on those same days took.
I liked the break out room discussions, I think I could have used more discussion in class that was casual without feeling like I was being put on the spot
Asynchronous days were a little longer than they said they would be

The asynchronous elements were very unenjoyable. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, the combination of asynchronous work and homework added up to a lot of independent German work. It would have been a fine amount of work if it involved interacting with other students, but because I was alone, it was not particularly fun.
Zoom Seminar worked, Async worked, but Canvas tests were unpleasant. Maybe some other method of testing?

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is great to learn another language and the German department has been so helpful in my learning process.
no, German is really hard
Yes. Teaches German well
Honestly, this is probably the kind of course that you take because you have to or because you know you'll enjoy it. In either case, I guess I would recommend it?
I would (and have). German is useful and this level was very informative.

Would definitely recommend, especially with Thorsten. He put a lot of care into teaching this course and restructured it to what we weren't understanding each day. Even though it was all virtual, I still got a lot out of it.
